comment.author: 34427469121@N01
comment._content: From The Powerhouse Museum's "Photo Of The Day" blog: "If you look at the larger version of this image on Flickr you can see several signs have been placed on the building that reads ‘Many happy returns of the day’. You can clearly see a large group of people gathering out the front of the building and some of the ferries are full of passengers. What was so special about this day?"

comment.author: 34427469121@N01
comment._content: Looks like it might be something about Mort & Co.? www.mortco.com.au/history.html "The name Mort & Co has been associated with Australia’s agricultural industries for decades. This link was first established in 1843 when Thomas Sutcliff Mort established Mort & Co as an auctioneering and brokering business specifically focusing on selling wool. This business developed and became a leading pastoral house before merging with R Goldsbrough & Co in 1888 to form Goldsbrough Mort & Co. Goldsbrough Mort & Co continued to grow, and in 1962 merged with Elder Smith & Co to form Elder Smith Goldsbrough Mort & Co Ltd. Consolidation continued, and in 1981 Elder Smith Goldsbrough Mort & Co Ltd merged with Henry Jones IXL to form Elders IXL which today trades as Elders. Charlie Mort, the proprietor of Mort & Co is a great-great-great nephew of Thomas and is proud of the mark that his ancestors have had on the Australian agricultural industry."

comment.author: 34427469121@N01
comment._content: Info about the founder, Thomas Mort: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Sutcliffe_Mort ... which says he apparently died in 1878, so it wasn't his birthday, if indeed this pic is from 1900 :)

comment.author: 34427469121@N01
comment._content:
I was wondering if it might have something to do with the ferries... and they just hung the note on the Mort & Co. building because it was right there ;)

Not sure if a merger would be classified as a birthday, as such...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: @ Powerhouse Museum Collection - the Justice and Police Museum is one corner south. Tweddle's Belmore Hotel "First & Last" as seen from the other direction: www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2362703683/

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: In researching the Belmore Hotel, I came across this earlier photo of the Mort & Co. building. They must have duplicated it and added a few floors. With its Victorian Italianate architecture it looks like a Venetian palace in many of these old photos. acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=167892

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Another Tom Roberts 'coincidence' - "Circular Quay 1899" AGNSW www.artgallery.nsw.gov.au/collection/works/348.1985/

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Two years later ... solved! It was "Anniversary Day" , Thursday 26 January 1888. Now known as Australia Day. Thanks to acquired knowledge and the treasures of Trove, a newspaper search for "orange benefit society picnic" produced this advertisement about half way down column 2, page 3, of the SMH for 21/1/1888 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13673540?searchTerm=oran... The relevant text - " ...LOYAL ORANGE BENEFIT SOCIETY OF AUSTRALASIA PICNIC in the AVENUE on ANNIVERSARY DAY JANUARY 26. POPULAR BRASS BAND, DANCING IN THE PAVILION Hot and Cold Water Free ... [list of sports] ... 9th Race,- Pig Hunt, must be caught by the tail only. [!!] Steamers Pearl, Rose, and Iris will leave the Floating Jetty Circular Quay, every half-hour from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. TICKETS, 1s 6d each. CHILDREN FREE. Tickets issued for Boxing Day are available. ... " It seems the Boxing Day picnic might have been cancelled (?) - a close inspection of the banner looks like the words were pasted over.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: But wait there's more ... It was The Centennial in 1888. 100 years since the colonization of Australia. Three days of celebration detailed at too-much-information level in the SMH of 27/1/1888, the following day. On page 8, column 1, about a third down the page, there is a description of the floating jetty at the end of Phillip Street (as in the photo above) nearly capsizing at 11 o'clock. From the shadows this photo was taken a couple of hours later, but it REALLY is quite spooky to read about what we are seeing. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/page/1391425?zoomLevel=5

comment.author: 34427469121@N01
comment._content: **applause**

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/george] [taking a bow!] Thanks, sorry it took so long! In column 1, page 9 of the same newspaper, there is a reference to the illuminations on the Mort & Co.Warehouse - " ... A large device was, however, displayed on the outside facing the Quay, with the appropriate centenary sentiment, "Many happy returns of the day". ..." trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/page/1391426?zoomLevel=5

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] B R I L L I A N T ! Another instance that demonstrates you are the master at dating photos (almost to the hour) by using Trove's Digitised Newspapers. You can't hear them, but rest assured the Lurkers are applauding too, in free wifi hotspots the world over - www.youtube.com/watch?v=-M1c7itPy3Y (they dress well those Lurkers!). And belatedly added to the 'Equivalents' gallery [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet/galleries/72157624679501001]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/lifeasdaddy] Thanks for the heads up. [blushing!]

I am thinking that many of the wonderful Henry King photos in the Tyrrell Collection show scenes at the time of the Centennial in 1888.  The yacht races, Naval ships etc.   And decorated King Street - 
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2363501042/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: My hunch is working. There is another Henry King photo "CIRCULAR QUAY, SYD. LOOKING W" which shows the view to the right of this taken from further north on east Circular Quay, (almost like a panorama). The Mort & Co. Warehouse has a sign up saying "DAY" to match this photo. So it must be the same date. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2362661905/] from.ph/30561

comment._content: (!) There's a good full page pic of the Goldsborough Mort wool store in the Sydney Mail, 17/10/1906 (p. 999) ...this issue isn't available via Google News Archive...it's on microflim though.

comment._content: acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/albumView.aspx?acmsID=430589&amp... This same pic also appears in the Mort family album over at SLNSW (p. 13; pic 112) ...along with a couple of other repeats from the PHM Tyrrell Collection collection...
